channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: World Briefing: Program to Destroy Syria’s Chemical Weapons Is 75% Complete, Group Says
item.description: An official from the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons said Syria might not finish the job by a revised deadline of April 27, but might do so soon after.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Prosecutors Seek Arrest Warrant for Captain of Capsized Ferry
item.description: Prosecutors filed for warrants for the ship’s captain, the third shipmate and another crew member on criminal charges of deserting their ship and passengers.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN and SU-HYUN LEE
item.media:description: Lee Jun-seok, the ferry's captain, was brought into court in Mokpo, South Korea, on Friday.

item.title: Chinese Official Urges Russia and Central Asian Allies to Control Internet
item.description: Guo Shengkun, China’s minister of public security, said that Russia and Central Asian countries must prevent “external forces” from trying to overthrow governments and provoke revolutions.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: Russian Opposition Figure Faces Accusations of Libel
item.description: Alexei A. Navalny, Russia’s most prominent opposition leader, is accused of calling a Moscow politician a “drug addict,” a charge he denies.
item.dc:creator: By NOAH SNEIDER

item.title: Separatist Leader Vows to Ignore Deal Reached on Ukraine
item.description: The leader of a group that has seized government buildings in Donetsk said that his representatives were not at the talks in Geneva.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Denis Pushilin, center, spokesman for the pro-Russian Donetsk People'€™s Republic, told reporters on Thursday that the insurgents do not recognize the Ukrainian government.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: April 18
item.description: A procession in Kolkata, West Bengal, to mark the occasion of Good Friday.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Powerful Earthquake Rattles Mexico, Shakes Buildings
item.description: A powerful earthquake struck Mexico on Friday, shaking buildings in the capital and sending people running out into the street, although there were no early reports of major damage.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS
item.media:description: People evacuated buildings after a magnitude 7.5 earthquake shook Mexico City on Friday.

item.title: Japan Says It Will Resume Whaling Off Antarctica
item.description: Japan officials said the whaling, which they say is for research, would be redesigned to address objections raised by an international court.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Messages From Students on South Korean Ferry
item.description: Texts sent by Danwon High School students as their ferry began sinking on Wednesday morning express love, fear and despair.
item.dc:creator: By SU-HYUN LEE, JIHA HAM and CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: A candlelight vigil was held for the missing passengers of the sunken South Korean ferry on Thursday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Scandal Downs Chairman of a Top Chinese State Company
item.description: The downfall of Song Lin, former head of China Resources, has the trappings of a late-night drama, including accusations of illicit riches, extramarital sex and pictures taken in a bedroom.
item.category: Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (Communist Party of China)
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Off the Charts: Most G-7 Economies Still Struggling to Recoup Lost Jobs
item.description: Of all the major industrialized countries, only Germany and Japan have managed to return to their 2007 employment levels.
item.dc:creator: By FLOYD NORRIS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Prominent Scientist Welcomes Soil Pollution Report
item.description: A leading Chinese scientist welcomed the release of a government report on contaminants in soil, a first in the country, but questioned why it had been done in such an understated manner.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Chimneys from a state-owned lead smelter and foundry alongside agricultural fields in Anhui Province. The sign warns against constructing residential buildings within 800 meters.

item.title: Avalanche Kills 12 Sherpas on Mount Everest
item.description: The guides were at an altitude of 19,000 feet when the avalanche hit. Four people were missing and six were injured, a Nepalese Tourism Ministry official said.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR and BHADRA SHARMA
item.media:description: Mount Everest in 2009. An avalanche swept down a slope of Mount Everest on Friday, killing guides.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Court Sentences 4 Activists to Jail
item.description: The sentencing is part of a clampdown on the New Citizens Movement, which has called on government officials to disclose their financial assets.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Police officers outside the courthouse in Beijing on Apr. 8 during Ding Jiaxi's trial.

item.title: A Romanian Team That Welcomes All, if They Have the Talent
item.description: A.S.F. Fratia Bucharest, a soccer team in the Romanian fifth division, is the only club in its league run on the principles of equality and nondiscrimination.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES MONTAGUE
item.media:credit: Cristian Movila for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tudorel Mihailescu, the team's 47-year-old goalkeeper, has a left arm that does not extend beyond the elbow. “I always dreamed of being a goalkeeper,” he said.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Nationalist Leader in Scotland Wagers Career on Referendum
item.description: After a surprise majority win in Parliament in 2011, Alex Salmond of the Scottish National Party is fiercely seeking Scotland’s independence.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alex Salmond, who heads the Scottish National Party, is gambling his career on the outcome of a vote on independence in September.

item.title: India Ink: A Fractured Vote in Old Delhi Market
item.description: Chandni Chowk is one among the seven constituencies in the nation’s capital that make up the state of Delhi, which is seen as a potential bellwether for the national elections.
item.dc:creator: By VISHNU VARMA

item.title: India Ink: India Election Digest: April 18
item.description: What you need to know on Friday about India’s elections.
item.dc:creator: By SUHASINI RAJ
item.media:description: An official marking the thumb of a voter with indelible election ink at a polling station in Bangalore, India, on Thursday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: An Internet ‘Big V’ Opts for Abject Contrition
item.description: China released Charles Xue, an American businessman highly visible on Chinese microblogs who was detained in August on sex charges. He then appeared in state-run media endorsing the authorities’ treatment of him.
item.category: Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Charles Xue, at the China Internet Conference in Beijing on Aug. 13, 2013.

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Park Director Survives Shooting
item.description: Emmanuel de Merode, an internationally recognized Belgian conservationist who has been working to protect rare mountain gorillas in the Democratic Republic of Congo, was attacked Tuesday by unknown assailants.
item.dc:creator: By ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Thailand: 2 Journalists Face Charges
item.description: Thai authorities on Thursday charged two journalists with defaming Thailand’s navy in an online news report about the trafficking of refugees from Myanmar.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Intelligence Bill Approved
item.description: Turkey’s Parliament on Thursday passed a bill that increases the powers of the national spy agency and strengthens its immunity.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: South Sudan: U.N. Base Attacked
item.description: At least 20 people were killed and 60 were wounded in the attack on the base in Bor in Jonglei State, a United Nations official said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: U.N. Council Takes Up Question of Rights in North Korea
item.description: The United Nations appeared to move a step closer on Thursday to holding North Korea’s government accountable for what an investigative panel has called a history of crimes against humanity.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Michael D. Kirby, above in Geneva in February, led a U.N. panel that investigated North Korea.

item.title: In Scripted Surprise, Putin Answers Snowden on Spying
item.description: In a poke at the White House, Edward J. Snowden asked President Vladimir V. Putin about Russia’s surveillance practices during a televised question-and-answer session.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and ANDREW ROTH
